study_identification.title: Accommodating Site Variation In Neuroimaging Data Using Normative And Hierarchical Bayesian Models

study_characteristics.study_objective: Evaluate hierarchical Bayesian normative models that accommodate multi-site scanner effects when modeling age-related cortical thickness, and compare against two-stage harmonization approaches (regress-out, ComBat) for both predictive performance and residual site effects while retaining clinically useful information.

clinical_application_and_analysis.association_analysis: Assessed whether individual z-score deviations in the ASD test set retained clinically useful signal by examining region-wise prevalence of atypical deviations (|z|≥2 SD) relative to expected 5%, and by comparing model performance metrics (correlation, SRMSE, MSLL) indicating better scaling and variance retention in HBLM/HBGPM versus harmonization baselines.
clinical_application_and_analysis.key_findings_brief: Hierarchical Bayesian normative models (HBLM/HBGPM) best captured age-related cortical thickness with minimal residual site effects while preserving clinically informative deviations; two-stage harmonization (regress-out/ComBat) under-scaled predictions and lost >90% variance.
clinical_application_and_analysis.key_findings_detailed: On the held-out test set, mean ROI-wise correlation was 0.705 (HBGPM) and 0.694 (HBLM), exceeding mod. ComBat (0.568), ComBat (0.343), residuals (0.329) and raw (0.435). Test SRMSE was 0.064 (HBGPM) and 0.066 (HBLM), lower (better) than mod. ComBat (0.075), ComBat (0.085), residuals (0.085) and raw (0.085). MSLL and predicted vs. actual variance plots indicated HBR models retained appropriate variance scaling, whereas harmonization models were poorly scaled (loss >90% of original variance). Forest plots showed substantial site heterogeneity uncorrected, largely removed after HBLM/HBGPM.
clinical_application_and_analysis.key_limitations: Validation confined to within-domain ABIDE with within-site split; no external-domain validation; focus limited to cortical thickness (DK atlas) and automated QC; software implementation details not fully specified.
clinical_application_and_analysis.application_notes: Single-stage HBR modeling of site as a random effect provides an alternative to ComBat-style harmonization for normative modeling; comparisons included preserving vs not preserving age/sex variance in ComBat; training/test split preserved site/age/sex distributions.

general_notes.general_notes: ABIDE aggregated 20 samples from 17 sites (3T scanners) with varying sequence parameters; site heterogeneity documented (Table 1). Site-specific sample sizes, sex ratios, and age ranges are listed (see Table 1 excerpt). Overall HC age statistics computed from sex-stratified means/SDs and counts.
